Sue SerinoShow Caption of ExpandBy Paul Kirby | pkirby@freemanonline.com | Daily Freeman and Paul KirbyPUBLISHED: September 21, 2020 at 11:25 a.m. | UPDATED: July 21, 2021 at 5:11 a.m.Abortion has become a hot-button issue in the race for New York’s 41st Senate District seat.
Challenger Karen Smythe, a Red Hook Democrat, says incumbent Sue Serino, R-Hyde Park, was wrong to vote against New York’s Reproductive Health Act (S240), which was approved by the state Legislature and signed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo last year. Serino’s campaign defended the senator’s vote.
“Serino’s ‘no’ vote shows that, for all her small-government GOP posturing, she wants to curtail women’s rights and their ability to control their own bodies,” Smythe said in a prepared statement.
The Democrat said the act “would not have passed, or even gotten to the floor for a vote, if Senate Democrats hadn’t won the majority in 2018.”
“We need to sustain and build this majority to make sure New Yorkers’ reproductive freedoms are protected no matter what happens at the federal level,” Smythe said. 
The Serino campaign, also in a prepared statement, said the senator “did the right thing in voting against this dangerous legislation and focusing instead on advocating for policies that actually help women: fighting to make our community more affordable for families, securing unprecedented funding for our schools, standing against policies that erode public safety, and advocating for legislation to expand professional opportunities for women across the state.” 


Smythe said the death on Friday of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg means the court “could overturn Roe v. Wade (the 1973 ruling that legalized abortion nationwide) in the very near future. That is why I am calling out Senator Sue Serino for her ‘no’ vote on New York’s Reproductive Health Act.”
“Sue Serino has proved, time and again, that she is not a woman who supports women,” Smythe said. 


The Republican’s campaign responded that, as the first woman to represent the 41st Senate District, “no one has fought harder for women in this community than Senator Serino.”
New York’s 41st Senate District encompasses all of Dutchess County (except the towns of Pawling and Beekman) and the Putnam County towns of Kent, Philipstown and Putnam Valley.
Serino is seeking a fourth two-year term representing the district. The race between her and Smythe is a rematch of the 2018 election, which Serino won by a slim margin.
